Transcription for 556318

So basically, if we can start with your memory of when you first found out about the disaster, what happened?
Yes. I think we probably heard about it on the news, didn't we, that an oil tanker had run aground in the mouth of the Milford Haven estuary.
I thought, crumbs, that's just down the road. So I was working at the time, so on my first day off we jumped in the car and drove down there.
I can remember seeing it stuck on the mid-channel rocks, sort of heaving up and down.
One thing that particularly sticks in my mind is that as a wave went over the ship, the ship was virtually underwater, as the wave went over,
so you could see a fountain of oil forced up and squirting out all over the place. A tremendous amount of oil came out.
I think the wind was northerly, which pushed the oil out to sea.
If the wind was what it usually is from the south-west, it would have pushed the oil right up the Milford Haven estuary and it could have easily reached Halford West and Blackpool Mill.
I don't know which was the worst, because the oil was washed out to sea and it went all the way up the coast.
I can remember a week or so later we went to Tenby and we saw the harbour was a thick layer of slowly heaving muck.
I can't think of any other description. The South Beach was like a tired road.
They were trying desperately to clear it, but the wheels of the trailers that they were carrying the stuff away in was carrying the mud up the road.
The road was a sort of sheen of dirty, smelly, stinking oil.
The shops had got lots of cardboard so that people coming off the street into the shop, at least some of the oil, went off their shoes on this cardboard rather than spoil the carpets.
Horrible business.
Fortunately, coming on 20 years later, I think Mother Nature is more or less back to normal.
Things seem to be normal. You see the little creatures in the rock pool swimming about.
I think some creatures come back more quickly than others. There are some species that are very slow.
I'm not a marine biologist, but you look at things, oh, that's familiar. I've seen that before.
Oh, I know what that is, I think. But some have recovered and others are a little more behind, as it were.
We had a nasty old business all around.
When they were doing the clean-up, who was involved in that then? Did you see people locally around here?
Well, virtually everybody that was out at work was given a suit of oil skins, a pair of thick gloves, either a brush or a spade or something, and a bag.
They were literally shoveling this stuff up and putting it into bags and buckets and barrels.
I can remember they had a couple of aircraft.
I think they were the old DC-3s flying low over the water and dropping chemicals on this heaving mass on the sea to break it up.
I think it was called gambling. That was supposed to break up the floating stuff, but the stuff that had been washed ashore, it was setting and it was making a horrible mess.
Troubledist, and the birds were washed in.
Ruth Griffiths told me that she was involved with that to a degree. They catch the birds and clean the oil off their feathers, but the trouble was it was ingested, so they had oil inside.
Cleaning the feathers meant that the feathers weren't waterproof anymore, so if you put the poor thing in the water it would sink.
A seagull that can't swim, it had all sorts of impact on things.
Was there anybody telling people how to do it properly?
I think it was very much a sort of ad hoc thing.
A sort of spur of the moment, an air of desperation, let's get at this.
It's one of those things that nobody had thought of before, so they had to do things almost on the hoof as it were.
I think it was a good idea to try and mobilise people, find the clean-up gear, get all these, I think there were two aeroplanes, to get them to come to drop the chemicals, buy the chemicals.
It was quite a logistical exercise because it wasn't just around Angle. As they say, it was in Tenby and all the little beaches all the way along the coast.

a allwch chi ddod,
a ddod â llwybau?
Dwi ddim yn credu bod yn oed,
dwi ddim yn cwblio'r pethau yn oed,
ond dwi ddim yn gallu ddod unrhyw beth oherwydd.
Roeddwn i'n dweud,
pan oeddwch chi'n rhani, rydw i'n googled,
ac mae llawer o ffotograffau ar Google,
ac mae yna lle rydw i'n ddod â llwyb 1996.
Felly, ddolwg i.
Mae'n dda, mae'n dda.
